Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Chinese.

I learned a baseline knowledge of Chinese. It is now possible for me to have a conversation about more than me and my family. I can now hold conversations talking about summer plans, weather, how often I do things, and so much more.

SO MUCH. Basic Chinese fluency and literacy -- the essentials you need to be able to communicate with people. (writing was a bit iffy this semester due to covid, but I understand it's usually great as well!)
Very good building of foundation off of CHNS 110. You will feel much more comfortable with grammar, vocabulary, etc. after this class
Elementary Chinese grammar and vocabulary - enough to perform everyday tasks and basic conversations in Chinese.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course material, overall, was very interesting and fun. Most of the vocabulary and grammar was helpful for learning Chinese, and the textbook was helpful. The pace we learned the characters at was sometimes too fast for me, as I often found myself behind on memorizing characters.

Strengths: Chinese acquisition.
Weaknesses: Hard to stay focused 5 days a week over zoom.

The class is, while hard, very interesting. Learning Chinese in that class is a very rewarding process. The instructors know it is hard but rewarding so they in turn are very encouraging. The workload for the course is heavy but necessary to get a deeper understanding of the language and its mechanics.

Strengths: daily classes, phenomenal instructors, good homeworks... basically everything

Weaknesses: none? perhaps a bit more turned-in writing practice (but I think this change was due to covid only)

Strengths: So well-organized, with many opportunities to practice different elements of the language. Probably one of the best ways to learn Chinese in the entire world.
Weaknesses: Some lessons were much more difficult than others. The early lessons in the first half were quite difficult, and completed with rapid pace. In contrast, later lessons were far easier and completed in a similar time frame.

The course is intensive, you need to study every day! But this means you learn more Chinese than you think possible in a semester, so it's a definite strength. The only weakness is the one-on-one tutorial. It's the only time to have live conversation practice, but too often they just turn into prepared answers and responses that don't practice live use of the language. Other than that though, the course was a really well-organized language class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: All good.

This class would only improve by removing many of the COVID implementations. Being in person would help people to learn characters better, have a closer connection with the small class, and improve the learning experience.
I think the class adapted very well to the COVID pandemic. If anything, my 4:30PM section was the largest one, so it was harder to have opportunities to practice/speak.

The virtual format worked well. The only thing to improve is the virtual one-on-one tutorials.  It's the only time to have live conversation practice, but too often they just turn into prepared answers and responses that don't practice live use of the language

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if I knew they could handle the workload.

Yes; Wang laoshi (Yu-Lin Saussy) is an incredible and super fun professor! She taught difficult concepts very well, and the class was very engaging. She is my favorite professor I have had at Yale. Despite being a very high workload, I highly recommend Chinese, especially with Wang laoshi. Just be prepared to spend a lot of time for this class.
Yes. You probably have to take it.
I would recommend taking Chinese to people who are willing to accept a challenge. Even though it is difficult, the reward is so much greater than the pain that is endured
Yes! the chinese department is great
YES take this course!!! Wang laoshi is amazing, and you won't regret it!
Absolutely 100%. Yale's Chinese Program is so well-designed and will teach you solid fundamentals
Yes, you'll leave knowing more Chinese than you thought you could learn in a semester!
